photo.description: The walls depict battles scenes showcasing military victories won by Florence (mainly against Pisa and Siena).
photo.title: Walls of the Salone dei Cinquecento

photo.description: The Salone dei Cinquecento (Hall of the Five Hundred) was built in 1495 during Savonarola's rein. The hall was designed to hold the Grand Council which consisted of 1500 members (only a third could fit in the room at a time). When the Medici returned to power, they used the room to hold audiences. Today, the room is used by the government of Florence (there was an event going on while I was there).
photo.title: Salone dei Cinquecento
Another Painted Ceiling in the Palazzo Vecchio
Painted Ceiling in the Palazzo Vecchio

photo.title: Palazzo Vecchio

photo.description: Ceiling of one of the rooms in Palazzo Vecchio.
photo.title: Palazzo Vecchio

photo.description: Quite literally the City Hall of Florence since 1872, construction on this castle or palace was started in 1299, under the careful eye of Arnolfo di Cambio, the architect of the Duomo and the Santa Croce church. It has served as a local and regional seat of government, a palace for nobility, a prison, and most recently a musem. It was originally called the Palazzo della Signoria, after the Signoria of Florence, the local ruling body. It has also gone by the names Palazzo del Popolo, Palazzo dei Priori, and Palazzo Ducale,depending on what the building was being used for and by whom at any given point in history. Palazzo Vecchio now refers to the fact that it is an "old palace." Most of the bulding is currently a rather interesting and quite spectacular museum, though it is still the seat for the city government, as well as the offices of the Mayor of Florence.
photo.tags: italy italiavacation palzzo vecchio old palace
photo.title: Palazzo Vecchio - Florence, Italy

photo.title: Palazzo Vecchio

photo.description: Bronzino designed sixteen of a series of twenty tapestries on the Story of Joseph, woven by the Flemish weavers Jan Rost and Nicolas Karcher. They were commissioned to decorate the walls of the Sala dei Duecento of the Palazzo Vecchio. They are on display in the Sala dei Gigli during the exhibit on Bronzino held at Palazzo Strozzi.
